child.pub-comments: This subgrouping scenario assumes no Austro-Thai node (Starosta, Sagart 2005:186).

child.pub-comments: Author says that Eastern Mon-Khmer split into five subgroups, but Vietic is the only one he names (Starosta 2005: 192).

root.pub-comments: The scenario proposed here “is almost certainly wrong in a number of points. Its potential utility is in helping to focus scholars' efforts on particular specific questions, resulting in the replacement of parts of this hypothesis with better supported arguments” (194). While this does represent some original ideas, “much of it is just a rearrangement of the ideas of various colleagues” (Starosta, Sagart 2005:182).
root.geography: North China Plain; Han River, Wei River, and central Yellow River (Huang He) areas of Central China, between Huang He and the Yangzi.
root.publications: Starosta, Stanley. 2005. Proto-East Asian and the Origin and Dispersal of the Languages of East and Southeast Asia and the Pacific. In Roger Blench, Laurent Sagart & Alicia Sanchez-Mazas (eds.), The Peopling of East Asia: Putting together archaeology, linguistics and genetics, 182-197. New York: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-32242-1
